Hamilton was also responsible for helping to author the Federalist Papers, a series of essays advocating for the ratification of the U.S. Constitution.

Following the war, Hamilton's commitment to building a strong central government earned him a position as the first Secretary of the Treasury under President George Washington. In this role, he established a national banking system, formulated economic policies, and issued policies to improve the nation's credit.

Despite his accomplishments, Hamilton's political career was also marred by personal and professional rivalries. The most notable rivalry was with Aaron Burr, the sitting Vice President at the time, which ultimately led to the infamous duel in which Hamilton was fatally shot and died on July 12, 1804.

Throughout his life, Alexander Hamilton remained a staunch advocate for a strong central government and a commercial economy, shaping the economic and political landscape of the United States. His vision, intellect, and influence were instrumental in the establishment of the nation's foundations, and his legacy continues to be felt in American society today.
